p.s: Romeo and Juliet express their love through their language in the extract.
Juliet states that [hear] ears have not yet drunk a hundred words of that tongue's utterance (ll. 58f).
This personification of her ears and Romeo's Tonguetongue highlights how she can notcannot hear enough of him speaking.
The Metaphormetaphor with love's ligh wings did I o'er-perch these walls showcases how Romeo feels empowered by her love.
Afterwards the metaphor there lies more peril in thine eye than twenty of their swords (ll. 71f) makes it obvious that Romeo is more afraid of being rejected by Juliet than killed by the Capulets.
Furthemore the personification of Lovelove giving Romeo advice (ll. 80f) shows how much he loves Juliet and that his love is big enough to take control over him.
Juliet constitutes her love for Juliet through the metaphor thy gracious self [...] is the god of my idolatry.
Generally, Romeo and Juliet both use a lot of metaphors to describe a lot of unbelievable aspects of their love against the odds.
